Welcome to **Applied Physics** - where theory meets the real world!

## What you'll learn:
- **Simple Machines** - Levers, pulleys, and mechanical advantage
- **Fluid Dynamics** - Bernoulli's principle and applications

> ðŸ’¡ **Fun Fact:** Simple machines have been used since ancient times - the Egyptians used ramps and levers to build the pyramids!

slides.title: Simple Machines: Overview
slides.content:
# Simple Machines âš™ï¸

Simple machines make work easier by changing the direction or magnitude of force.

## The Six Simple Machines

1. **Lever** - Rigid bar on a pivot
2. **Pulley** - Wheel with rope/cable
3. **Wheel and Axle** - Circular motion transfer
4. **Inclined Plane** - Sloped surface
5. **Wedge** - Moving inclined plane
6. **Screw** - Wrapped inclined plane

## Mechanical Advantage (MA)

```
MA = Output Force / Input Force
   = Distance In / Distance Out
```

## Key Principle: Conservation of Energy

```
Work In = Work Out (ideal machine)

F_in Ã— d_in = F_out Ã— d_out
```

- Higher MA = Less force required
- BUT you must move a greater distance!

## Efficiency

Real machines lose energy to friction:

```
Efficiency = (Work Out / Work In) Ã— 100%
```

| Machine | Typical Efficiency |
|---------|-------------------|
| Lever | 90-98% |
| Pulley | 85-95% |
| Inclined plane | 80-90% |
| Screw | 25-80% |

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Point:** Simple machines trade force for distance - you can't get something for nothing!

A pulley is a wheel with a grooved rim for a rope or cable.

## Types of Pulleys

### Movable Pulley

- Reduces force by half
- MA = 2
- Must pull rope twice as far

### Block and Tackle
Combination of fixed and movable pulleys:

```
MA = Number of rope sections supporting load
```

| Pulley System | MA |
|---------------|----|
| 1 fixed | 1 |
| 1 movable | 2 |
| 1 fixed + 1 movable | 3 |
| 2 fixed + 2 movable | 4 |

## Example

**A 4-pulley system (MA=4) lifts a 400 N weight. What force is needed?**

F = 400 / 4 = **100 N**

But you must pull 4 times the distance!

## Real Applications

| Application | Pulley Type |

| Elevator | Multiple pulleys + counterweight |
| Crane | Block and tackle |
| Sailing | Various pulley systems |
| Gym equipment | Cable and pulley |

> ðŸŽ¯ **Trade-off:** More pulleys = less force needed, but more rope to pull!

# Inclined Planes & Screws ðŸ”©

## The Inclined Plane

A ramp that reduces the force needed to raise a load.

```

```

### Mechanical Advantage

```
MA = L / h = Length / Height
```

### Example

**Ramp is 5 m long, 1 m high. What is MA?**

MA = 5 / 1 = **5**

100 N needed instead of 500 N!

## Practical Uses

| Application | Why? |
|-------------|------|
| Wheelchair ramps | Gentle slope easier |
| Loading docks | Move heavy items |
| Mountain roads | Switchbacks reduce steepness |
| Pyramids | Ancient builders used ramps |

## Bernoulli's Equation


| P | Static pressure |
| Â½ÏvÂ² | Dynamic pressure |
| Ïgh | Pressure due to height |

slides.title: Introduction to Astrophysics
slides.content:
# Introduction to Astrophysics ðŸŒŒ

Astrophysics applies physics to understand celestial objects and phenomena.

## What is Astrophysics?

| Pure Astronomy | Astrophysics |
|----------------|-------------|
| Where objects are | How objects work |
| Observation | Physical explanation |
| Cataloging | Modeling and theory |

## Key Questions Astrophysics Answers

- How do stars shine?
- How do galaxies form?
- What is the fate of the universe?
- Are we alone?

## Tools of Astrophysics

| Method | What it tells us |
|--------|------------------|
| **Spectroscopy** | Composition, temperature, velocity |
| **Photometry** | Brightness, distance |
| **Astrometry** | Positions, motions |
| **Multi-messenger** | GW, neutrinos, EM waves together |

## The Electromagnetic Spectrum in Astronomy

| Wavelength | Reveals |
|------------|--------|
| Radio | Cold gas, pulsars |
| Infrared | Dust, forming stars |
| Visible | Stars, galaxies |
| UV | Hot stars |
| X-ray | Black holes, neutron stars |
| Gamma | Extreme events |

## Fundamental Physics Used

- Gravity (Newton â†’ Einstein)
- Thermodynamics (stellar interiors)
- Nuclear physics (stellar fusion)
- Electromagnetism (radiation)
- Quantum mechanics (spectra)

> ðŸŽ¯ **Insight:** Astrophysics is applied physics on the grandest possible scale!

slides.title: Black Holes
slides.content:
# Black Holes ðŸ•³ï¸

A black hole is a region where gravity is so strong that **nothing, not even light, can escape**.

## Formation

### Stellar Black Holes
- Massive stars (> 25 Mâ˜‰) collapse after supernova
- Mass compresses to tiny volume
- Escape velocity exceeds c

### Other Types

| Type | Mass | Formation |
|------|------|----------|
| Stellar | 5-100 Mâ˜‰ | Massive star death |
| Intermediate | 100-10âµ Mâ˜‰ | Mergers? |
| Supermassive | 10â¶-10Â¹â° Mâ˜‰ | Galaxy centers |
| Primordial | Any | Early universe? |

## Anatomy of a Black Hole

```
                    â”‚
    Singularity  â—  â”‚ â† Matter crushed to point
                    â”‚
    â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â• â† Event Horizon
    (Point of no return)
                    â”‚
    Photon sphere   â”‚ â† Light orbits here
                    â”‚
    Accretion disk â—â”‚â— â† Infalling matter, glows X-ray
```

## Schwarzschild Radius

```
Rs = 2GM/cÂ²
```

| Object | Schwarzschild Radius |
|--------|---------------------|
| Earth | 9 mm |
| Sun | 3 km |
| 10 Mâ˜‰ star | 30 km |
| Sagittarius A* | 12 million km |

## Time Near Black Holes

- Time slows dramatically near event horizon
- Distant observer sees objects "freeze" at horizon
- Falling observer experiences normal time (but tidal forces!)

## 2019: First Black Hole Image!

Event Horizon Telescope captured M87* - a supermassive black hole 55 million light-years away.

> ðŸ’¡ **Paradox:** Black holes are the simplest objects (mass, spin, charge) yet most mysterious!

# Cosmic Rays â˜„ï¸

Cosmic rays are high-energy particles from outer space that constantly bombard Earth.

## What Are Cosmic Rays?

|-------------|------------|
| Protons | ~87% |
| Helium nuclei | ~12% |

The highest energy cosmic rays carry the kinetic energy of a baseball, concentrated in a single proton!

## Sources

| Energy Level | Probable Source |
|--------------|----------------|
| Low | Sun (solar wind) |
| Medium | Supernova remnants |
| High | Active galactic nuclei |

## Detection Methods
